docs.lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said last night that the city had begun preliminary talks to have the Metropolitan Transportation Authority take over the routes of seven private bus companies that operate in the city. Workers at three of the companies are on strike in Queens. Speaking at a town meeting in Ozone Park, Queens, Mr. Bloomberg said his administration was ''talking to the M.T.A. about taking over private bus companies.'' The details of the proposal were unclear yesterday. The bus companies are heavily subsidized by the city, which owns many of the buses and stations.

headline.main: City Seeks M.T.A. Takeover Of 7 Bus Companies' Routes

docs.abstract: New York City is in preliminary talks to have Metropolitan Transportation Authority take over routes of seven private bus companies that operate within city and which are heavily subsidized by city; workers at three companies are on strike for health benefits comparable to those given to city employees (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A consumer group said today that prices of the 50 drugs most often prescribed for elderly people rose last year at nearly three times the rate of inflation. The report was issued by the consumer group, Families USA, as House Republicans tried to round up votes for their bill to provide prescription drug benefits to the elderly under Medicare. The bill, approved last week by two House committees, is scheduled for a vote on the House floor this week.

headline.main: Study Finds Top Drugs for Aged Easily Outpace Inflation

docs.abstract: Consumer group Families USA says prices of 50 drugs most often prescribed for elderly people rose last year at average 7.8 percent, nearly three times rate of inflation; report is issued as House Republicans try to round up votes for bill to provide prescription drug benefits to elderly under Medicare (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IF you suffer from chronic stage fright, like Patricia Barber, you might want to think twice about playing in the lobby studio of Sirius Satellite Radio, which is on the 36th floor of a highrise office building in Midtown. Three of its four walls are made of thick glass. (The fourth is covered by a back-lighted picture of the pre-Sept. 11 skyline of Manhattan, with the World Trade Center glowing serenely at dusk.) Everyone outside can see everything inside. It's hard to imagine a more uncomfortable space for a musician who is, as Ms. Barber describes herself, a ''reluctant performer.'' Yet one sunny day this month, she was bent over the studio piano, warming up her fingers with Fats Waller's perky ''Jitterbug Waltz'' and discreetly looking away from the passers-by who clustered in the hall to check her out. She always does that. When she makes her Carnegie Hall debut on Tuesday, opening for Cassandra Wilson at the JVC Jazz Festival, she will have a tranquilizing snort of brandy, kick off her shoes (she plays barefoot) and look upstage, trying to pretend there's no one out there.

headline.main: Singing, and Thinking, With a Serious Purr

docs.abstract: Article on singer-songwriter Patricia Barber, who is about to make her Carnegie Hall debut, opening for Cassandra Wilson at JVC Jazz Festival; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Fourteen years ago Joan Rattner Heilman wrote an article in Parade magazine on discounts and privileges for people over 50. She then thought it might be a good idea for a book but her agent at the time didn't agree. Not daunted, Ms. Heilman sold it on her own. This spring Contemporary Books printed the 14th edition of Ms. Heilman's ''Good Deals and Great Adventures That You Absolutely Can't Get Unless You're Over 50'' ($14.95). The guidebook has sold close to a million copies, and Ms. Heilman describes herself as ''undoubtedly the major guru on the subject of senior privileges.''

headline.main: Longevity for a Book On the Perks of Aging

docs.abstract: Contemporary Books prints 14th edition of Joan Rattner Heilman's guidebook Good Deals and Great Adventures That You Absolutely Can't Get Unless You're Over 50; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: There are probably not many places, even in the West Village, where a woman can dress an Asian jagged-shell turtle up in a bow, put her in the back of a modified Barbie Jeep Cherokee festooned with fake ivy and pull her around a schoolyard without attracting an enormous amount of attention. The New York Turtle and Tortoise Society's annual show, held yesterday outside the Village Community School on West 10th Street, is one of them.

headline.main: West Village Journal; A Hard Shell Hides Man's Best Reptilian Friend

docs.lead_paragraph: THE party celebrating the face-smoothing wonders of Botox was in full swing when the host, Dr. Laurence Kirwan, pointed to a photograph on the wall of his office in Norwalk that showed him and other plastic surgeons treating Croatian children with war injuries. It was as if to say that giving a party for the latest wrinkle reducer and going on a United Nations mission were not entirely at odds with each other. They are both about improving the quality of life, he said.

headline.main: A New Face on the Party Scene: Botox

docs.abstract: Scene described at one of series of Botox parties attended by more than 40 women and one man at Dermis Center for Skin and Body Health in Norwalk, Conn; patients pay $300 to $1,000 a treatment, depending on doctor, three to four times a year, which is not covered by insurance; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ALEXANDER M. CUTLER worked his way up through three recessions. Unlike many chief executives, he has learned to thrive in downturns, and has made his reputation that way at the Eaton Corporation, the giant manufacturer based here. This downturn, however, has been different. ''The recession we've been through,'' Mr. Cutler said, ''was as steep as anything we've seen since 1981 and 1982,'' which stands as the worst since World War II. ''Everybody keeps comparing what just happened to the mild '90-'91 recession. That totally misses it.''

headline.main: Ready for an Upturn. Not Ready to Spend.

docs.abstract: Eaton Corp chief executive Alexander M Cutler, whose company's woes reflect manufacturing as whole, is skeptical of national statistics that signal strong economic recovery is under way; shuns risk of spending to expand Eaton because of severity of recession's effects on company, which has closed 19 plants and cut 12,000 jobs, or 20 percent of its work force; photos; charts (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: MAYBE this will be the year when Congress finally passes the biggest expansion of Medicare since 1965 and gives prescription drug coverage to 40 million elderly and disabled Americans. But almost nobody here is betting on it. Instead, the widely held expectation is that the long political stalemate on health policy will continue -- that a nation that has learned to tolerate 39 million uninsured will also, at least for another year, tolerate millions of elderly struggling to cope, largely on their own, with soaring drug costs. Democrats and Republicans alike will go home this fall, denounce each other as obstructionists and promise, if re-elected, to do something about prescription drugs for the elderly -- next year. And this time, maybe, they will really, really mean it.

headline.main: The Nation: The Prescription Drug Debate; Why the Elderly Wait . . . and Wait

docs.abstract: Long political stalemate over nation's health care policy reviewed; nation that has learned to tolerate 39 million uninsured people will also tolerate, at least for another year, millions of elderly people struggling to pay soaring drug costs; photo; graphs; issues involve partisan advantage, but also fundamental disagreement involving Republican preference for 'choice' and 'free market' over government-run Medicare (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: David Denenberg, moved by the death of a friend on Sept. 11, wrote a $100 check to the Robin Hood Relief Fund in Manhattan last October. Today, though, the fund has disbursed just a little more than half of the $59 million it raised, and so Mr. Denenberg is uncertain that his modest gift got to the people for whom he expressly intended it: the families of civilian victims killed that day.

headline.main: Families Fret as Charities Hold a Billion Dollars in 9/11 Aid

docs.abstract: Donors and recipients of aid continue experiencing enormous frustrations over administration of private charity, nine months after terrorist attacks on World Trade Center; donors feel charitable organizations have not fully honored their wishes for their contributions, and recipients believe charities are 'dragging their feet;' frustration stems from fact that charities have yet to distribute total of roughly billion dollars in aid; charity officials insist they have by and large met immediate needs of victims and are responsibly looking forward to financing future, longer-term needs (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IN October last year, the medical journal The Lancet published a study asserting that mammograms do not save lives and, in fact, cause many women to undergo painful and unnecessary treatments. Because this news directly challenged orthodox belief, the community of breast cancer experts and advocates was thrown into turmoil. Distinguished expert panels declared that their confidence in mammography was shaken. A prominent oncologist announced that she had no immediate plans to continue having routine mammograms. The president of a national breast cancer advocacy group publicly regretted the mammogram that diagnosed her own cancer years ago.

headline.main: Doubts on Mammograms Do Not Affect Their Use

docs.abstract: Dr Marcia Sherman on why women continue to have mammograms despite study published in Lancet in October 2001 that found that mammograms do not save lives and, in fact, cause many women to undergo painful and unnecessary treatments; photo (M)
